item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘ubiquitous’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 576 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: La rivalidad entre babuinos sugiere que los monos también sienten celos
item.description: Se observó que los primates jóvenes de un parque natural al sur de África interferían constantemente cuando su madre prestaba atención a un hermano o hermana menor.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

media:content.media:credit: Dr. Axelle Delaunay

item.title: Word of the Day: ubiquitous
item.description: This word has appeared in 576 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Spain’s Approach to Migration Is Overrated and Harmful
item.description: It appears democratically unworkable and may be stoking populism.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Caldwell

media:content.media:credit: Emilio Morenatti/Associated Press

item.title: Lawmakers Spar with Bondi Over Epstein Files
item.description: Attorney General Pam Bondi, sitting in a room with survivors of the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, refused to apologize for the Justice Department’s handling of the Epstein files during a House Judiciary Committee hearing.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Los archivos Epstein sacuden el mundo
item.description: Figuras prominentes han sido señaladas más allá de las fronteras de EE. UU., y les ha costado sus puestos de trabajo, su reputación e incluso han surgido amenazas de cargos judiciales.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

media:content.media:credit: Uma Sanghvi/The Palm Beach Post, vía Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein en el tribunal de West Palm Beach, Florida, en 2008.

item.title: Así fue como la líder de Japón rescató a su partido del abismo
item.description: Tras solo 110 días en el cargo, Sanae Takaichi, la primera mujer electa como líder de Japón, consiguió lo que parecía imposible hace solo unos meses: la mayor victoria electoral en los 71 años de historia del Partido Liberal Democrático.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández

media:content.media:credit: Foto de consorcio por Franck Robichon
media:content.media:description: La primera ministra de Japón, Sanae Takaichi, en una rueda de prensa celebrada el lunes en Tokio.

item.title: Olympic Figure Skaters Are on Thin Ice Over Music Copyright Rules
item.description: Several athletes have found themselves caught up in controversies over musical choices before and during one of the biggest competitions of their careers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Canadian ice dancing pair Zachary Lagha and Marjorie Lajoie performing on Saturday in Milan.

item.title: Turkish Nobel Novelist Orhan Pamuk Gets the Netflix Series He Wanted
item.description: After publishing more than 20 books and winning a Nobel Prize, the Turkish author fought to bring a celebrated novel to the screen — on his own terms.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Emin Ozmen

media:content.media:description: Orhan Pamuk in his office in Istanbul, in an apartment building named for his family.

item.title: India’s Prime Minister Faces Blowback Over Trade Deal With Trump to Lower Tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi won a big reduction of sky-high tariffs, but critics say he undermined Indian sovereignty and undercut the nation’s farmers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli

media:content.media:credit: Altaf Hussain/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India secured a new trade deal with the United States that had few details.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 12, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 12, 2026.

item.title: Quote of the Day: G.O.P.’S CASH LEAD GIVES DEMOCRATS MIDTERM ANXIETY
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 12, 2026.

item.title: Judge Halts Transfer of Former Death Row Inmates to Federal ‘Supermax’ Facility
item.description: A judge ruled that the Trump administration’s plan to send the men to the nation’s harshest prison rendered their attempts to challenge the transfer a “sham” process.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Buildings and guard towers at the federal corrections center in Florence, Colo., also known as the “Alcatraz of the Rockies.”

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 12, 2026
item.description: Kareem Ayas shows some affection.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: U.S. Attorney Chosen to Replace Trump Pick Is Quickly Fired by White House
item.description: Federal judges had appointed Donald Kinsella, a veteran litigator, as top prosecutor in the Northern District of New York after the Trump administration’s nominee was found to be serving unlawfully.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich

media:content.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: John Sarcone III, pictured, had been appointed U.S. attorney for the Northern District of New York by President Trump. Donald Kinsella was chosen on Wednesday to replace him.

item.title: México podría estar a punto de perder su estatus de país libre de sarampión
item.description: Meses antes de que millones de personas lleguen para la Copa del Mundo, los casos confirmados en el país han superado los 9000 desde el año pasado.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

media:content.media:credit: Marco Ugarte/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Una trabajadora de la salud administrando una dosis de la vacuna contra el sarampión en Ciudad de México la semana pasada. “Estamos seguros que se va a controlar el brote”, dijo el miércoles la presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: Why Nancy Guthrie’s Disappearance Is Breaking Through the Noise
item.description: A vulnerable victim, an unknown perpetrator and a recognizable celebrity are all factors in a case that has captivated the public.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley

media:content.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Elements of Nancy Guthrie’s kidnapping case have set it apart, including the universality, and relatability, of the victim: an elderly mother in peril.

item.title: Where to Stream ‘Varsity Blues’ and James Van Der Beek’s Best Performances
item.description: The actor seemed to understand early on that his lasting legacy would be the title character of “Dawson’s Creek.” But he found ways to subvert his all-American persona.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: This Comet Stopped Spinning. Then It Started Rotating Backward.
item.description: The unusual event, never seen before, might be a way small comets are “blown to bits” in the solar system.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O’Callaghan

item.title: Trump Says He Will Now Invite Democrats to Governors’ Meeting
item.description: Even as he reversed course on excluding Democrats, the president repeatedly attacked a Republican governor who had planned to oversee the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump denied that he had ever sought to exclude Democrats from the meeting.

item.title: Eyeing the Midterms, Kennedy Pivots Toward Food and Away From Vaccines
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who focused heavily on vaccine policy in 2025, will spend this year talking up healthy eating.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg

media:content.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the boxer Mike Tyson and Brooke Rollins, the agriculture secretary, at an event on Wednesday promoting Mr. Kennedy’s healthy eating agenda.

item.title: ‘The Other Place’: Tobias Menzies and Emma D’Arcy in a Psychosexual Sophocles Update
item.description: In Alexander Zeldin’s naturalistic adaptation of “Antigone,” Tobias Menzies and Emma D’Arcy star as a feuding uncle and niece.
item.dc:creator: Helen Shaw

media:content.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The cast of “The Other Place,” from left: Lee Braithwaite, Emma D’Arcy, Ruby Stokes and Tobias Menzies at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: Bangladesh Holds First Elections After 2024 Student Protests
item.description: At the vanguard of Gen Z movements, protesters in Bangladesh ousted the prime minister in 2024. They now face the hard reality of winning change through elections.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Saif Hasnat and Lam Yik Fei

media:content.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times

item.title: How Trump Sees the World: It’s Personal
item.description: Historical relationships play little if any role in the second-term worldview of the president, who holds himself as the constant center of global events.
item.dc:creator: Karen Yourish, William B. Davis and Tim Wallace

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Baby, 17 Days Old, Found Dead From Fire That Killed Her Mother
item.description: Two days after a fatal house fire in Queens, firefighters returned to the wreckage and found Emma Alcantara’s body. She and her mother, Miguelina, lived in an illegal basement apartment.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Olivia Bensimon

media:content.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The mother and baby who died in a Queens fire lived in a basement that had not been certified for occupancy. Seven other residents and two firefighters were injured.

item.title: Top U.S. Energy Official Presses Venezuela to Do More to Spur Investment
item.description: Energy Secretary Chris Wright is one of the highest ranking American officials to visit Venezuela in nearly 30 years, marking warmer ties between Washington and Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero

media:content.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Amuay refinery, Venezuela’s largest, in Punto Fijo, Falcón state.

item.title: Nurses at 4 N.Y.C. Hospitals Vote to End Strike, but It Continues at One
item.description: At Montefiore and Mount Sinai hospitals, health care workers ratified a deal to end the walkout, but nurses remain on the picket line at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Nurses at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital will continue their strike even as health care workers elsewhere approved a contract.

item.title: Artforum’s Top Editor Will Step Down
item.description: The magazine announced that two other editors there will jointly replace Tina Rivers Ryan, who has been in the role since 2024.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: James Van Der Beek: The ‘Dawson’s Creek’ Star’s Life and Career in Photos
item.description: The actor was best known for his early roles in “Dawson’s Creek” and “Varsity Blues.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

media:content.media:credit: Warner Bros.

item.title: Four States Sue Administration Over Loss of Public Health Funds
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, claim the cuts were intended as retribution and will harm efforts to control H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted infections.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli

media:content.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The agency administered block grants for H.I.V. prevention that were allocated to public health departments in California, Colorado, Illinois and Minnesota.

item.title: ‘Dawson’s Creek’ Heartthrob James Van Der Beek Dies at 48
item.description: James Van Der Beek, who played the wide-eyed, overly sensitive main character on the popular turn-of-the-millennium TV drama series “Dawson’s Creek,” died on Wednesday at age 48.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

item.title: ‘Hot Girls for Zohran’ Co-Founder Floated Conspiracy Theories About Israel
item.description: Kaif Gilani was fired from Brad Lander’s House campaign after his social media history, which included praise for Hamas and virulent attacks on the police, emerged.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

item.title: Mexico May Be on Brink of Losing Its Measles-Free Status
item.description: The country’s confirmed cases have topped 9,000 since last year, raising fears that a high-stakes evaluation in April could lead to its status being revoked.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

media:content.media:credit: Marco Ugarte/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A health worker administering a dose of the measles vaccine in Mexico City last week. “We are confident that the outbreak will be controlled,” President Claudia Sheinbaum said on Wednesday.

item.title: House Passes Strict Voter ID Bill, Amplifying Trump’s Claims of Fraud
item.description: The measure had no path forward in the Senate, where Democrats are all but certain to block it and Republicans have said they will not try to skirt filibuster rules to ram it through.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni

media:content.media:credit: Jim Vondruska for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The strict voter identification measure would require proof of American citizenship to vote and allow the Department of Homeland Security to seize voter rolls in any state.

item.title: Bud Cort, Who Starred in 1971’s ‘Harold and Maude,’ Dies at 77
item.description: The role, one of his first, made him a household name and a film idol of the anti-establishment 1970s. But it also limited his growth as an actor.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

media:content.media:credit: CBS, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Bud Cort as the teenager Harold Chasen who falls in love with a 79-year-old woman in Hal Ashby’s movie “Harold and Maude,” from 1971. Panned at first, it became a cult classic.

item.title: In His Second Act, James Van Der Beek Starred Online as a Proud Dad and Family Man
item.description: The actor, who died on Wednesday, was most famous for “Dawson’s Creek,” but as he got older, he let fans into his real life as a father of six.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

media:content.media:credit: Alex Goodlett/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: James Van Der Beek, who died on Wednesday, with two of his six children at a charity event in 2023.

item.title: Are Antidepressants Safe During Pregnancy?
item.description: Confusion about the safety of taking the drugs during pregnancy has led to mental health emergencies for some expectant mothers, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

media:content.media:credit: Claire Merchlinsky/The New York Times; Photographs by Getty

item.title: Trump Orders Dept. of Defense to Buy Electricity From Coal Sources
item.description: Mr. Trump is trying to revive coal, the dirtiest fossil fuel. At the White House, coal executives awarded him a trophy as the “Undisputed Champion of Beautiful Clean Coal.”
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order. On the desk beside him is a trophy labeled “Undisputed Champion of Beautiful Clean Coal.”

item.title: Tamas Vasary, Pianist of Power and Sensitivity, Dies at 92
item.description: He bought technical brilliance and stylistic authority to Romantic-era music, particularly the works of Chopin and Liszt.
item.dc:creator: Tim Page

media:content.media:credit: Erich Auerbach/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Tamas Vasary around 1965. He was best known for his many recordings, most of them on the Deutsche Grammophon label.

item.title: Democratic Hopefuls in Michigan’s Senate Race Jostle for Union Support
item.description: Can Democrats win back working-class voters? These candidates are trying.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Associated Press
media:content.media:description: From left, the top Democratic Senate candidates in Michigan: Representative Haley Stevens, Dr. Abdul El-Sayed and State Senator Mallory McMorrow.

item.title: Former Colombo Boss Is Going Back to Prison for Meeting With Mob Members
item.description: Theodore Persico Jr., once picked to lead one of New York’s five crime families, was supposed to stay away from his former associates. But he nonetheless attended a Christmas party in Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A judge in Federal District Court in Brooklyn found Theodore Persico Jr.’s meeting with mob members to be a violation of the terms of his supervised release.

item.title: The El Paso Airspace Closed After the Military Tested New Technology
item.description: Also, the attorney general faces lawmakers’ anger over Epstein files. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El Paso International Airport today.

item.title: Democrats Denounce Attempt to Indict Lawmakers for Illegal Orders Video
item.description: Members in both chambers warned the failed attempt to prosecute the six lawmakers amounted to an existential threat to the legislative branch.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “If the executive branch can merely attempt to prosecute members of the legislative branch for simply exercising free speech, that is not a Democratic problem or a Republican problem, it is a constitutional crisis,” said Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the minority leader.

item.title: Why Are People ‘Becoming Chinese’ on Social Media?
item.description: Think of the meme as an absurdist joke, a wellness goal or an ironic expression of protest — or all of the above. Your ethnicity is beside the point.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Will You Take the Sex Plant?’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring stories of no more than 100 words submitted by readers.

media:content.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Gallup Will No Longer Track Presidential Approval Ratings
item.description: The monthly poll has been used to measure presidential performance for almost nine decades.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gallup’s decision comes as President Trump has escalated his threats against the press, and has sued several news media organizations, including at least one pollster, over the last several years.

item.title: How an F.B.I. Affidavit to Seize Ballots Relied on Debunked Election Claims
item.description: summary
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Nick Corasaniti and Richard Fausset

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Ken Peplowski, Who Helped Revive the Jazz Clarinet, Dies at 66
item.description: Also a saxophone standout, he served as stylistic bridge between the Benny Goodman swing era and the genre-blurring present.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ken Peplowski in 2010 with the guitarist James Chirillo at the Lucille Lortel Theater in Manhattan. The musician and critic Russell Davies once called Mr. Peplowski “arguably the greatest living jazz clarinetist.”

item.title: What Homeowners Need to Know About Smart Home Cameras
item.description: A new Super Bowl ad is raising questions about the power of doorbell cameras.
item.dc:creator: Dorie Chevlen

media:content.media:credit: Smith Collection/Gado/Getty Images

item.title: Canada Updates: Police Identify Suspect in Mass Shooting
item.description: The 18-year-old fatally shot her mother and stepbrother as well as six people at a school, before killing herself. Her motive was unclear, but police had visited her home several times for mental health issues.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Eagle Vision Agency/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
